story_headline: Hunter: Joe Biden would do ‚Äòanything I want him to‚Äô
story_copy: A new audio tape from Hunter Biden‚Äôs laptop reveals the President‚Äôs son was saying Joe Biden would do anything that he would ask him to. The tape was released by the Washington Examiner on Tuesday.In the audio, Hunter relayed the message that business deals overseas exposed him to undue foreign influence, which he could pass on to Joe Biden.‚ÄúHe‚Äôll talk about anything that I want him to, that he believes in,‚Äù Hunter stated. ‚ÄúIf I say it‚Äôs important to me, then he will work a way in which to make it a part of his platform.‚ÄùRepublicans have said Hunter‚Äôs multi-million deals in Ukraine in China could have influenced the Biden administration‚Äôs policy in those countries as well as at home in the US. However, Hunter downplayed any political risks of his questionable businesses.‚ÄúMy dad respects me more than he respects anyone in the world, and I know that to be certain,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs not going to be about whether it affects his politics‚Ä¶‚ÄùSen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) and Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) are continuing their investigation into Joe and Hunter Biden‚Äôs foreign businesses dealings. They said a deeper probe would begin after midterm elections.
image_caption: Joe Biden, left, and his son Hunter Biden, right, in Vancouver, Canada. (Photo by Bruce Bennett/Getty Images)

story_headline: Biden admin. continues to engage with Asian leaders
story_copy: Biden admin. continues to engage with Asian leadersSecretary of State, Antony Blinken shakes hands with South Korean Foreign Minister Park Jin at the State Department in Washington, Monday, June 13, 2022, after a news conference. (Roberto Schmidt/Pool via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:57 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022Biden administration diplomats have continued to push their influence on world affairs through Asia. On Monday, Secretary of State Antony Blinken held a press conference with South Korean Foreign Minister Park Jin. The two top diplomats took aim at North Korea.The US-South Korea and North Korea relations have been strained since Joe Biden took over the presidency. Biden has continued to order joint military drills between America and South Korea‚Äôs military. This has garnered threats from Kim Jong-un‚Äôs regime who have equated those exercises to declarations of war.Last week, Kim called to bolster the country‚Äôs military while claiming the international sphere is a ‚Äúaggravating environment.‚Äù The rouge state has launched dozens of ballistic missile tests so far this year and US Intelligence officials warned another test of a nuclear weapon is on the horizon.Secretary Blinken stressed, if North Korea wants to be taken seriously by international leaders then it will have to gain favor through diplomacy.‚ÄúA nuclear test would be dangerous, it would be deeply destabilizing to the region,‚Äù stated the US official. ‚ÄúIt would blatantly violate international law as set out in multiple United Nations Security Council resolutions, so we urge the DPRK to refrain from further destabilizing activity. We call on the DPRK to engage in serious and sustained diplomacy.‚ÄùAmerica‚Äôs top diplomat went on to say North Koreans could be negatively affected if its government continues its path toward instability.‚ÄúWe want to support the people of North Korea, including with COVID-19 vaccines,‚Äù Blinken noted. ‚ÄúIndeed, we have offered our help consistently throughout the pandemic and again during the awful surge that they are now enduring, which comes on top of severe economic and humanitarian crises. Our goal, simply put, is a peaceful and stable region and world. Until the regime in Pyongyang changes course, we will continue to keep the pressure on.‚ÄùMeanwhile, State Department Deputy Secretary Wendy Sherman was sent to Vietnam to cement ties with Hanoi. Sherman touted the US has pledged nearly 20 million to help clean up any unexploded ordinances left over from the Vietnam war. Additionally, she promised to work with Vietnamese officials to combat illegal wildlife trafficking.U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman shakes hands with Vietnamese Foreign Minister Bui Thanh Son in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Monday, June 13, 2022. Sherman is visiting Vietnam, the last stop in her Asian trip after South Korea, the Philippines and Laos. (AP Photo/Hoang Duong)Both countries seem to agree that they are integral partners and can be a strong influence for the Association of Southeast Asians Nations (ASEAN).‚ÄúWe agree with you our partnership is critical to ensure an independent and prosperous Vietnam,‚Äù said Sherman. ‚ÄúWe have great respect for each other‚Äôs systems and our joint efforts are to build a better future for our people.‚ÄùI had a productive meeting with @FMBuiThanhSon today in Hanoi. We discussed ways we can elevate the U.S.-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and support @ASEAN centrality. pic.twitter.com/aTvvzpWOF4‚Äî Wendy R. Sherman (@DeputySecState) June 13, 2022Additionally, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin met with Thai defense officials in Bangkok. The military leaders discussed modernizing Thailand‚Äôs military in several areas, including cyber security and space technology.These discussions were met with the wrath of the Chinese Communist Party who has taken aim at the Biden administration for trying to turn leaders in the region against them. Chinese officials claim that along with engaging in diplomatic relations with Asian officials, the US is also making allegations that China wants to subjugate Taiwanese residents.‚ÄúThe US‚Äô remarks vilifying China will not fool the international community, but only compromise its own credibility,‚Äù stated Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Wang Wenbin. ‚ÄúWe urge the US to match its words with deeds, follow through on its commitment not to seeking confrontation or conflict, not to seeking ‚Äòa new Cold War‚Äô or ‚Äòan Asian version of NATO‚Äô or forming antagonistic blocs in the region.‚ÄùChinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin. (Reuters Photo)The latest developments in the Biden-Asia relations landscape seems to show the Biden administration can follow it‚Äôs promise to bolster the region at the expense of the CCP.
image_caption: Secretary of State, Antony Blinken shakes hands with South Korean Foreign Minister Park Jin at the State Department in Washington, Monday, June 13, 2022, after a news conference. (Roberto Schmidt/Pool via AP)

Stefanik: Americans Care More About Inflation, Crime, Southern Border Than January 6TOPICS:Antony BlinkenASEANAsiaAssociation of Southeast Asians NationsBANGKOKBiden AdministrationCCPChinaChinese Communist PartyCOVID-19COVID-19 vaccinesCyber SecurityDPRKJoe BidenKim Jong UnLloyd AustinnewsNorth KoreaNUCLEAROANOANNPark JinpoliticsSouth KoreaspaceState DepartmentTECHNOLOGYThailandVaccinesVietnamWang WenbinWarWendy Sherman SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: N.Y. governor approves abortion safe haven laws
story_copy: N.Y. governor approves abortion safe haven lawsNew York Gov. Kathy Hochul delivers her first State of the State address in the Assembly Chamber at the state Capitol, Wednesday, Jan. 5, 2022, in Albany, N.Y. (AP Photo/Hans Pennink, Pool)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:42 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022New York Governor Kathy Hochul (D) signed a bill expanding abortion access in the Empire State. She approved six bills to make her state a ‚Äúsafe haven‚Äù for the procedure in case the Supreme Court rules Roe v. Wade to be unconstitutional.‚ÄúOur heart goes out to the women in those other states, we‚Äôll be there for the women of other states,‚Äù stated the governor. ‚ÄúAnd mark my words, just never, never, here in the state of New York because New York has always been a beacon for those yearning to be free. And I want the world to hear that that will never change‚Äù.The laws are intended to provide legal protections for both abortion participants and providers from outside states where the operation may be outlawed, including the prevention of New York authorities from cooperating with outside law enforcement agencies in abortion-related investigations as well as restricting out-of-state medical malpractice insurance claims against New York abortion providers. Additionally, Empire State abortion providers will be immune to professional misconduct charges while institutions that refuse to perform abortions may be sued.Under one of the provisions, abortion providers may even obscure their addresses in order to evade legal action. The governor also announced the formation of a task force that will research the effects of pro-life pregnancy centers. Hochul alleged these protections for abortion are by extension protection for so-called ‚Äúbodily autonomy.‚Äù‚ÄúBecause as the first female governor of New York, I take this personally and that‚Äôs a fight I‚Äôm willing to take on,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúNot just on behalf of the women of New York, but for women all across this nation. I refuse to go backwards and I promise you, as long as I‚Äôm governor, we will not because these are rights that have been fought for, for generations. And New York State has led every step of the way.‚ÄùDespite championing bodily autonomy, Hochul maintained former Governor Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs health care worker COIVD-19 vaccine mandate,. On top of that, New Yorkers were required to be vaccinated to participate in various indoor activities earlier this year.Meanwhile, the Supreme Court could hand down its decision on Roe as soon as Wednesday. Should the measure be stricken down, each state will have sovereignty over its own abortion policy.
image_caption: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul delivers her first State of the State address in the Assembly Chamber at the state Capitol, Wednesday, Jan. 5, 2022, in Albany, N.Y. (AP Photo/Hans Pennink, Pool)
more_news: ¬†Attorney McBride: J6ers Are 100% Being Politically TargetedTOPICS:abortionabortion policyAndrew CuomoConstitutionEmpire StateHealth Carekathy hochulNew YorknewsOANOANNpoliticspro-lifeRoe v. WadeSupreme Courtunconstitutionalvaccine mandate SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Hunter Biden‚Äôs ex-wife speaks out on marriage, finances
story_copy: Hunter Biden‚Äôs ex-wife speaks out on marriage, financesFILE ‚Äì Hunter Biden walks with his then-wife Kathleen, along with Vice President Joe Biden and Jill Biden for the internment services for Sen. Edward Kennedy at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Va, on Aug. 29, 2009. Kathleen Buhle, the ex-wife of President Joe Biden‚Äôs son Hunter, says she has ‚Äútotal control over my life now,‚Äù five years after her divorce, as she opens up about her marriage in a new memoir. (Jim Bourg/Pool via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:04 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022Hunter Biden‚Äôs ex-wife Kathleen Buhle recently discussed their 24-year marriage. In an exclusive interview with ABC Tuesday, she said she had her ‚Äúhead in the sand‚Äù regarding their finances and wouldn‚Äôt be able to testify about the matter in court.EXCLUSIVE: Kathleen Buhle, Hunter Biden‚Äôs ex-wife, to @arobach on his addiction issues: "He was struggling under a massive drug addiction. And that's heartbreaking and painful.‚Äù https://t.co/uKNXDXuD4y pic.twitter.com/dKXvfHKtyC‚Äî Good Morning America (@GMA) June 14, 2022However, Buhle noted Biden has always acknowledged the benefit and advantage of coming from a prominent family. She also called her decision to let Biden completely control their finances ‚Äúembarrassing.‚Äù‚ÄúThis was one of the harder parts for me to write and to acknowledge,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs embarrassing to say that I seated all financial control to my husband.‚ÄùWhen asked why, Biden‚Äôs ex responded with, ‚ÄúI liked the nice things and I didn‚Äôt want to think about the cost at which they were coming. Writing this book really helped me to understand how unfair that was to Hunter and how unhealthy that was for me.‚ÄùBuhle also touched on Biden‚Äôs struggles with substance abuse, while suggesting they did not discuss it very often since there was so much shame around the topic.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Hunter Biden walks with his then-wife Kathleen, along with Vice President Joe Biden and Jill Biden for the internment services for Sen. Edward Kennedy at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Va, on Aug. 29, 2009. Kathleen Buhle, the ex-wife of President Joe Biden‚Äôs son Hunter, says she has ‚Äútotal control over my life now,‚Äù five years after her divorce, as she opens up about her marriage in a new memoir. (Jim Bourg/Pool via AP)

story_headline: NATO Chief: Sweden taking ‚Äòimportant steps‚Äô to meet Turkey‚Äôs demands
story_copy: NATO Chief: Sweden taking ‚Äòimportant steps‚Äô to meet Turkey‚Äôs demandsSweden‚Äôs Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, right, welcomes NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg at Harpsund, the country retreat of Swedish prime ministers, in Sodermanland County, Sweden, Monday, June 13, 2022. (Henrik Montgomery/TT News Agency via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:21 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022Sweden is taking steps to meet Turkey‚Äôs demands for approving its NATO membership application. That‚Äôs according to NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg who visited Sweden on Monday. Both Sweden and Finland requested to join the alliance last month.Great to meet with Prime Minister @MarinSanna of our close partner #Finland in Washington. We discussed the need to address #Turkey's concerns & move forward with the #NATO membership application by Finland & Sweden. pic.twitter.com/wPTjhYHMLy‚Äî Jens Stoltenberg (@jensstoltenberg) June 3, 2022Turkish officials objected while accusing the two Scandinavian countries of supporting the Kurdistan Workers‚Äô Party, which is a group designated as a terrorist organization by Turkey, the United States and the European Union.‚ÄúI welcome that Sweden has all started to change its counterterrorism legislation and that Sweden will ensure that the legal framework for arms export will reflect their future status as a NATO member with new commitments to allies,‚Äù stated Stoltenberg. ‚ÄúThese are two important steps to address concerns Turkey has raised.‚ÄùGood to meet President @niinisto to discuss #Finland‚Äôs application for #NATO membership. We are taking the security concerns raised by #Turkiye seriously & will remain in close contact with our Ally T√ºrkiye & partners Finland & #Sweden to find a common way forward. pic.twitter.com/fUq1hQCsQk‚Äî Jens Stoltenberg (@jensstoltenberg) June 12, 2022The NATO Secretary General said the goal is to have Sweden and Finland join NATO as soon as possible.
image_caption: Sweden‚Äôs Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson, right, welcomes NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg at Harpsund, the country retreat of Swedish prime ministers, in Sodermanland County, Sweden, Monday, June 13, 2022. (Henrik Montgomery/TT News Agency via AP)

story_headline: ‚ÄòPipeline Fire‚Äô swells to 20K acres in Ariz.
story_copy: ‚ÄòPipeline Fire‚Äô swells to 20K acres in Ariz.People evacuate their home as the Pipeline Fire burns in the mountains above Flagstaff, Ariz., Sunday, June 12, 2022. The fire has forced the evacuation of several hundred homes. (Jake Bacon/Arizona Daily Sun via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:24 AM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022A wind-driven wildfire forces hundreds of evacuations near Flagstaff, Arizona. According to reports Tuesday, the Pipeline Fire sparked Sunday and has scorched 20,000 acres.Two additional fires, the Haywire Fire and Double Fire, are straining firefighting efforts in the region. Officials said strong winds are fueling the flames and helping them spread. Flagstaff declared a state of emergency, activating additional state and federal resources.I have just signed a Declaration of Emergency for the Pipeline Fire. pic.twitter.com/GKutJKR7vK‚Äî Flagstaff Mayor Paul Deasy (@MayorDeasy) June 13, 2022The Coconino County Sheriff‚Äôs Office arrested Mathew Riser, a homeless man camping in the area, for violating the forest‚Äôs fire ban. Riser was reportedly burning used toilet paper, but has not yet been charged for directly causing the Pipeline Fire. He‚Äôs due in federal court on Thursday.Views from the O'Leary Webcam at 360 Overwatch tonight at 8:28 p.m.  give us an idea of just how far this fire has spread‚Ä¶ from the peak to the valley below. The views we're accustomed to will be black come morning. This is why we obey burn bans! #PipelineFire #azwx pic.twitter.com/YRhcKbajpM‚Äî NWS Flagstaff (@NWSFlagstaff) June 14, 2022Meanwhile, a Red Cross evacuation center has been established and will be operating out of Singaua Middle School. Shelter will be provided for residents who have evacuated. Fire officials are urging citizens to use caution when traveling and to stay up-to-date with developments.
image_caption: People evacuate their home as the Pipeline Fire burns in the mountains above Flagstaff, Ariz., Sunday, June 12, 2022. The fire has forced the evacuation of several hundred homes. (Jake Bacon/Arizona Daily Sun via AP)

Stefanik: Americans Care More about Inflation, Crime, Southern Border than January 6OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:37 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, June 13, 2022House Republican Conference chair, Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.) asserted that Americans are more worried about skyrocketing inflation than the events of January 6. story_copy: $1.5M donation to Uvalde, Texas communityFILE ‚Äì Education Secretary Miguel Cardona speaks during the 2022 National and State Teachers of the Year event in the East Room of the White House in Washington, April 27, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:15 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, June 13, 2022The Department of Education announced a major donation to the community and victims of the Uvalde, Texas school shooting. On Monday, ‚ÄúProject School Emergency Response to Violence‚Äù granted $1.5 million to the Uvalde Independent School District.This comes shortly after Secretary of Education Miguel Cardona visited the school and vowed to support recovery efforts.‚ÄúNo community should have to experience a tragedy like this alone,‚Äù said Cardona. ‚ÄúWhile in Texas, I saw the Uvalde community come together in deep and meaningful ways to support one another and all the families who lost loved ones. It is our turn to support them.‚ÄùNo community should be forced to shoulder a tragedy alone. Today, @USEdGov is deploying Project SERV resources to the Uvalde Consolidated Independent School District in response to the tragic events of May 24th.‚Äî Secretary Miguel Cardona (@SecCardona) June 13, 2022Project SERV funds are available for use under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. They can be used for activities that help restore a sense of safety and security for the district‚Äôs students, teachers, staff, and families.‚ÄúIn the hours and days since that tragic day, we have committed to providing the Uvalde community with every available resource they may require from the Department,‚Äù the secretary voiced. ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs release of these emergency funds is an initial step that will be followed by technical assistance and on-the-ground supports in the months and years to come.‚ÄùAccording to the Department of Education, this will include funds for summer programs, new mental health services and overtime pay for teachers and staff.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Education Secretary Miguel Cardona speaks during the 2022 National and State Teachers of the Year event in the East Room of the White House in Washington, April 27, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)

story_headline: Fed raises interest rate by 0.75%, biggest increase since 1994
story_copy: Fed raises interest rate by 0.75%, biggest increase since 1994FILE ‚Äì Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference at the Federal Reserve, Wednesday, May 4, 2022 in Washington. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce its largest interest rate hike since 1994 ‚Äî a bigger increase than it had previously signaled and a sign that the central bank is struggling to restrain stubbornly high inflation. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 11:43 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022As expected by many, the Federal Reserve is undertaking the biggest interest rate increase since 1994. On Wednesday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell announced the Central Bank is raising interest rates by 0.75 percent, which is up to a range of 1.5 to 1.75percent.This is the Fed‚Äôs latest attempt to bring down record-high inflation, which hit 8.6 percent in May. This marks the highest level in more than 40-years. Last month, the Fed raised interest rates by 0.5 percent, which was the biggest single rate hike since 2000.ÔªøA new poll has suggested a majority of Americans believe the country is headed in the wrong direction. In the Politico/Morning Consult survey released Wednesday, 74 percent of respondents said things in the US have gotten off on the wrong track compared to just 26 percent who said things are headed in the right direction.The poll also found 56 percent of respondents disapprove of the job Democrat President Joe Biden is doing in the Oval Office. This may comes as no surprise as high inflation, supply chain issues and other economic issues have prompted concerns of a potential recession.Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is expected to announce more hikes later this year, despite fears it may cause a recession, as officials are trying to bring inflation down to 2 percent. This comes as inflation woes have continued to hurt pocketbooks of every day Americans.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell speaks during a news conference at the Federal Reserve, Wednesday, May 4, 2022 in Washington. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce its largest interest rate hike since 1994 ‚Äî a bigger increase than it had previously signaled and a sign that the central bank is struggling to restrain stubbornly high inflation. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)
more_news: ¬†Biden Touts Economic Performance While Economists Warn Of RecessionTOPICS:Central BankECONOMYFederal Reserveinflationinterest rateJerome PowellnewsOANOANNpoliticsRECESSION SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Biden touts economic performance while economists warn of recession
story_copy: Biden touts economic performance while economists warn of recessionPresident Joe Biden addresses the AFL-CIO convention, Tuesday, June 14, 2022, in Philadelphia. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:02 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022President Joe Biden has continued to insist the economy is on the right track while economists warn of an impending recession. While speaking to union workers on Tuesday, Biden touted his economic performance despite record high inflation.‚ÄúThe bottom line is this; I truly believe we made extraordinary progress by laying a new foundation for our economy, which becomes clear once global inflation begins to recede,‚Äù claimed the President. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much at stake, but the truth is I‚Äôve never been more optimistic about America than I am today.‚ÄùWhile Biden is more optimistic than ever, economist don‚Äôt share the rose-colored outlook. According to a recent Financial Times survey, nearly 70 percent of economists expects the US to spiral into a recession in 2023. Biden then went to say he will continue to rely on foreign markets to bring down the cost of fuel, which has reached a national average of $5 a gallon according to AAA.‚ÄúSo I have a plan to bring down the cost of gas and food,‚Äù said the President. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to take time, but let the world coordinate the largest release. What I‚Äôll be able to do for the largest release of oil from the global fund in history. Million barrels a day and 240 million barrels to boost global supply. I convinced other nations to join us to keep prices from rise, keep prices from rising even more.‚ÄùBiden is set to visit to Saudi Arabia later this year to speak with the country‚Äôs Crown Prince about possibly importing some of their oil. Meanwhile, the American Petroleum Institute has put out a 10 point proposal that promotes domestic oil production, which they asserted is a better solution to ease the pain at the pump.‚ÄúThis is America, we can do any damn thing we put our minds tom‚Äù Biden stated. ‚ÄúAnd guess what? We‚Äôre not going back to the false promises of trickle down economics. We‚Äôre going forward.‚ÄùMy Administration will continue to do everything we can to lower prices for the American people, but Congress has to act as well. pic.twitter.com/TPxSpOSnVa‚Äî President Biden (@POTUS) June 13, 2022Despite all the warnings from experts, Biden remains convinced the American economy is improving under his administration. In the meantime, inflation continues to be a hot button issue for voters moving into the midterm elections.
image_caption: President Joe Biden addresses the AFL-CIO convention, Tuesday, June 14, 2022, in Philadelphia. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Trump‚Äôs picks win big in Nev., S.D., S.C. primaries
story_copy: Trump‚Äôs picks win big in Nev., S.D., S.C. primariesFILE ‚Äì State Rep. Russell Fry addresses a crowd awaiting former President Donald Trump, March 12, 2022, in Florence, S.C. Fry who is running against Rep. Tom Rice in the 7th District in the Republican primary has been endorsed by former President Donald Trump. (AP Photo/Meg Kinnard, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 7:21 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022It appears former President Donald Trump continues to have the Midas touch in the Republican Party as his picks dominated primaries in South Carolina, Nevada and North Dakota.The biggest news coming out of Tuesday‚Äôs contest was Trump-backed Russel Fry‚Äôs defeat of incumbent Rep. Tom Rice in South Carolina. Fry won with more than 51 percent, therefore, eliminating a no run-off. Rice, who voted to impeach Trump in 2021, said earlier Tuesday that Trump‚Äôs hold on the GOP was waning.‚ÄúI had hoped that the situation would have been reversed, but again, this seat doesn‚Äôt belong to me,‚Äù Rice stated. ‚ÄúIt belongs to the voters, right? It‚Äôs what they want‚Ä¶Fry became the first Trump-backed candidate to oust a GOP incumbent this primary season. However, Trump‚Äôs dark horse Katie Arrington was edged out by Rep. Nancy Mace by less than 10 points. Trump, who has shunned Mace over the past several months, congratulated her on Truth Social and asserted she should easily be able to defeat her Democrat opponent in November.Governor Henry McMaster was nominated for a second term in South Carolina with 83 percent of the vote.I am honored at the trust and confidence South Carolinians have placed in me as their Governor. ¬†Peggy and I would like to thank everyone for their support. Let¬†us continue working together. ¬†Let‚Äôs keep winning. The best is yet to come. pic.twitter.com/R13zVDEOas‚Äî Gov. Henry McMaster (@henrymcmaster) June 15, 2022Meanwhile in Nevada, former Attorney General Adam Laxalt won the state‚Äôs Republican Senate primary. The Trump-endorsee took more than 50 percent of the vote, while fending off a challenge from retired Captain Sam Brown. Laxalt will now advance to face Democrat incumbent Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto.I just called Adam Laxalt to congratulate him on a hard-fought primary win.The stakes are high. We must take back the U.S. Senate, the House, and the governorship. I will support Republican campaigns and work tirelessly to turn out every Republican in Nevada this November.‚Äî Sam Brown (@CaptainSamBrown) June 15, 2022Also in Neveda, Jim Marchant won the GOP nomination for the state‚Äôs Secretary of State with 36 percent of the vote. Finally in North Dakota, Senate candidate John Hoeven and congressional candidate Kelly Armstrong swept through the GOP primary with Trump‚Äôs backing.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì State Rep. Russell Fry addresses a crowd awaiting former President Donald Trump, March 12, 2022, in Florence, S.C. Fry who is running against Rep. Tom Rice in the 7th District in the Republican primary has been endorsed by former President Donald Trump. (AP Photo/Meg Kinnard, File)

story_headline: Republican flips blue House seat in Texas
story_copy: Republican flips blue House seat in TexasA campaign sign for Mayra Flores. (Denise Cathey/AP Photo)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:02 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022Republican House candidate Mayra Flores edged out her Democrat opponent in a Texas special election. Flores finished Tuesday with 51 percent of the vote, while Dan Sanchez came in second with 43 percent. Sanchez later conceded in a statement on Twitter.pic.twitter.com/6GzFpQ8BZI‚Äî Dan Sanchez (@dansancheztx34) June 15, 2022This is a historic win as the seat Flores will be filling until at least January was held by a Democrat for 10-years. Her win narrows the Democrat majority in the House and she will also be the first Mexican-born congresswoman to serve in the upper chamber.Making history in the #RGV!Congratulations to @MayraFlores2022 on her HUGE win tonight in #TX34! pic.twitter.com/w3BhrZhWeI‚Äî Texans for Abbott (@AbbottCampaign) June 15, 2022Flores touted Trump-era policies during her victory speech, while bringing attention to pain at the pump, high grocery costs and inflation under the Biden administration.‚ÄúPolicies are being placed right now are hurting us,‚Äù she stated. ‚ÄúWe cannot accept the increase of gas, of food, of medication. We cannot accept that and we have to say the facts that under President Trump, we did not have this mess in this country.‚ÄùFlores said she looks forward to standing strong for conservative values of faith, family and freedom in Washington. Meanwhile, Tesla and SpaceX CEO, Elon Musk even chimed in on her victory. He confirmed that she, in fact, received his vote in the Texas special election. Musk then alluded to a 2022 red wave.I voted for Mayra Flores ‚Äì first time I ever voted Republican. Massive red wave in 2022.‚Äî Elon Musk (@elonmusk) June 15, 2022
image_caption: A campaign sign for Mayra Flores. (Denise Cathey/AP Photo)

story_headline: Rep. Donalds: Biden has no idea how economy works
story_copy: Rep. Donalds: Biden has no idea how economy worksRep. Byron Donalds, R-Fla., speaks during a House Committee on Oversight and Reform hearing on gun violence on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday, June 8, 2022. (Jason Andrew/The New York Times via AP, Pool)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:13 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022According to congressman Byron Donalds (R-Fla.), President Joe Biden has no idea how the economy works. During a press conference on Tuesday, the Florida representative said the money Americans have to pay at the pump could be going to better use.üö® ICYMI üö®Yesterday, in a @housebudgetGOP committee hearing on the impact of President Biden‚Äôs American Rescue Plan, I outlined how this disastrous stimulus package has caused record-high inflation, soaring gas prices, and suffering for the American worker.Watch below ‚¨áÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/cCYNF8Ju5Z‚Äî Congressman Byron Donalds (@RepDonaldsPress) June 15, 2022While families struggle to pay for gas and put food on the table, consumer prices have increased significantly as well. US inflation rate increased to 8.6 percent last month, which is the highest in more than 40-years. Americans‚Äô personal finances are becoming considerably tighter.‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt take that vacation, you can‚Äôt go buy that new article of clothing, you can‚Äôt go do the next thing that you choose to do,‚Äù said Donalds. ‚ÄúThis inflation is the largest tax increase on poor families and middle income families in decades in the United States.‚ÄùThe Republican lawmaker called out President Biden for comments the President made about currently ‚Äúchanging people‚Äôs lives.‚Äù Donalds noted, by ‚Äúchanging people‚Äôs lives‚Äù the President means paying nearly $500 more monthly for essential goods and services. The congressman asserted that Biden has actually made Americans‚Äô lives worse.Meanwhile, other House Republicans have also criticized the Biden administration‚Äôs failing economic policies as inflation continues to be a hot button issue for voters moving into the midterm elections.

story_headline: Biden urges oil companies to ramp up production, slams profit margins
story_copy: Biden urges oil companies to ramp up production, slams profit marginsPresident Joe Biden walks to the Oval Office of the White House after stepping off Marine One, Tuesday, June 14, 2022, in Washington. Biden is returning to Washington after speaking at the AFL-CIO convention in Philadelphia. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:55 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022President Joe Biden has urged several top oil companies to ramp up production while taking aim at refiners for high profits amid soaring gas prices. In a letter to Exonn Mobil, Chevron and five other firms Wednesday, he said the companies must take immediate action to increase the gas and diesel supply.Gas is over $5, rising quickly, and Biden's response is to *mail a letter* to oil companies. What embarrassing impotence from President Biden.‚Äî Tom Cotton (@TomCottonAR) June 15, 2022The President said refiners historically high profit margins are worsening the intense financial pain the American people are feeling. These remarks came after Biden recently accused oil companies of purposefully curbing supply to raise prices.‚ÄúExxon made more money than God this year,‚Äù asserted the President. ‚ÄúAny by the way, nothing‚Äôs changed. One thing I want to say about the oil companies, they talk about how they have 9,000 permits to drill. They‚Äôre not drilling. Why aren‚Äôt they drilling? Because they make more money not producing more oil. The price goes up.‚ÄùLast week, President Biden blamed rising gas prices on America's oil companies, claiming they don't pay taxes & aren‚Äôt drilling enough oil.¬†Before that, he tried to blame rising prices on Putin.¬†The only place he hasn't placed blame is where it belongs: his energy policies.‚Äî Senator John Cornyn (@JohnCornyn) June 14, 2022Biden also informed the companies the federal government is prepared to use all tools and emergency authorities to increase capacity as well as output in the near term.

story_headline: Suspected Buffalo shooter faces hate crime and firearm charges
story_copy: Suspected Buffalo shooter faces hate crime and firearm chargesPayton Gendron is led into the courtroom for a hearing at Erie County Court, in Buffalo, N.Y., Thursday, May 19, 2022. Gendron faces charges in the May 14 fatal shooting at a supermarket. (AP Photo/Matt Rourke)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 11:11 AM PT ‚Äì Wednesday, June 15, 2022The suspected gunman accused of killing 10 people in a Buffalo supermarket is facing 26 counts of hate crimes and firearm offenses. The Department of Justice announced Wednesday that 18-year old Payton Gendron is being charged 10 counts of hate crimes resulting in death, three counts of hate crimes involving bodily injury and attempt to kill.Additionally, Gendron faces 10 counts of using a firearm to commit murder during and in retaliation to a crime of violence as well as three counts of using and discharging of a firearm during and in retaliation to a crime of violence.Attorney General Merrick B. Garland Delivers Remarks Announcing Accused Tops Shooter Charged with Federal Hate Crimes and Using a Firearm to Commit Murder https://t.co/YNkEsxJZMP‚Äî Justice Department (@TheJusticeDept) June 15, 2022During a ceremony held Tuesday, Buffalo Mayor Byron Brown held a 13-second moment of silence to honor the 10 killed and three wounded in last months shooting.‚ÄúTo the families who lost loved ones in the attack, words will never convey the heartbreak and pain this senseless tragedy has caused,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúI am grateful, we are all grateful that you are here today. And we want to be clear, that as a community, we are not going anywhere and we will always remember.‚ÄùIf convicted Gendron could face the death penalty.
image_caption: Payton Gendron is led into the courtroom for a hearing at Erie County Court, in Buffalo, N.Y., Thursday, May 19, 2022. Gendron faces charges in the May 14 fatal shooting at a supermarket. (AP Photo/Matt Rourke)

story_headline: Sen. McConnell slams Democrats for inflation
story_copy: Sen. McConnell slams Democrats for inflationFILE ‚Äì Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, of Kentucky, speaks during a news conference in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Timothy D. Easley, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:09 PM PT ‚Äì Tuesday, June 14, 2022Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) recently slammed Democrats for creating the worst inflation in decades. While speaking on the Senate floor Monday, the Kentucky lawmaker said President Joe Biden claimed inflation reached its peak months ago. Since that declaration, however, prices have only increased to their highest points in decades.In particular, McConnell said that prices for gas, food and rent have been particularly inflated. He then pointed out that most Americans are pinching pennies preparing for even greater increases. He said that the money Americans worked hard to earn just isn‚Äôt going as far as it once did.‚ÄúDay by day, all of these painful milestones add up to one simple reality,‚Äù stated the Senate Minority Leader. ‚ÄúAmericans hard earned dollars just aren‚Äôt going nearly as far as they once did. Runaway inflation has swallowed up any shot at rising pay bringing more prosperity.‚ÄùÔªøAs far as gas prices go, the Biden administration‚Äôs energy outlook forecast for 2022 revealed officials dramatically misunderstood the state of America‚Äôs energy supply. According to a Townhall report in December, Biden predicted gas prices would average $2.88 per gallon in 2022.At the beginning of January, however, gas prices were already at $3.13 a gallon and those prices have exceeded $5 a gallon nationally.The pain at the pump is getting worse as gas prices are inching higher by the day. According to the latest data from AAA, national average price of gas is up 15 cents from just last week and more than 55 cents from last month.Meanwhile, Biden has failed to take responsibility for the crisis and has blamed Russia‚Äôs Vladimir Putin and COVID-19 instead of his policies. McConnell‚Äôs floor speech came as the Wall Street entered a bear market with experts increasingly warning of a recession. On top of that, the May inflation report revealed the highest consumer price index since 1981.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, of Kentucky, speaks during a news conference in Louisville, Ky. (AP Photo/Timothy D. Easley, File)
